chapters.text: Mia froze at the entrance to the school gym, watching the other eighth graders practicing their routines for the upcoming dance competition. Everyone seemed to have a partner already—everyone except her. She spotted Tyler, the new boy who'd moved here last month, sitting alone on the bleachers. He was scrolling through his phone, seemingly unbothered by the chaos around him. Mia had barely spoken two words to him, but she was running out of options. The competition was in three weeks, and without a partner, she couldn't enter. As she walked toward him, her best friend Zoe grabbed her arm. "I have the perfect solution," Zoe whispered excitedly. "Just ask Tyler to be your dance partner and pretend you're dating. That way, nobody will tease you about being desperate for the competition. Plus, have you seen him move in PE class? The boy can dance!"

Mia couldn't believe her eyes as she watched the new boy glide across the floor with perfect rhythm. His feet moved quickly, hitting every beat while his arms swung with confidence. Other students had stopped to stare too. The boy—she thought his name was Ethan—had transferred to their school just last month and barely spoke to anyone. Yet here he was, dancing like he belonged on a TV show. Mia clutched her notebook tighter as an idea formed. Maybe she didn't need to sit out the competition after all. If Ethan could dance that well without a partner, perhaps he needed one too. Taking a deep breath, Mia stepped away from the gym entrance and walked toward him, rehearsing what she would say. The competition was only three weeks away, and she desperately wanted to participate. All she needed was the courage to ask him.

Mia took a deep breath and walked across the gym floor, her heart pounding in her chest. The colorful streamers hanging from the ceiling seemed to blur as she focused on Jake, who was standing by the water fountain. He smiled when he saw her coming, which made her steps a little lighter. Mia had practiced what to say all week in front of her mirror at home. Now was the time to actually do it. She stopped in front of Jake, her dance shoes squeaking slightly on the polished floor. "Hey Jake," she said, her voice coming out higher than normal. "I was wondering if you'd like to be my partner for the competition?" The words tumbled out quickly. Jake's smile grew wider as the music from the speakers changed to a faster song. The other students continued practicing around them, spinning and stepping in time to the beat.

Mia scanned the gym nervously, feeling like the only person without a dance partner. The colorful streamers hanging from the ceiling and the shiny basketball court reflected the bright overhead lights. She clutched her dance shoes tightly against her chest as she took a deep breath and stepped further into the room. The music was loud, a popular song that everyone seemed to know the steps to already. Mr. Garcia, the dance teacher, clapped his hands to the rhythm while counting "five, six, seven, eight!" Some students laughed when they missed steps, while others moved with confidence. Mia spotted her friend Zoe across the room, already paired with Tyler from math class. They were practicing a complicated twirl that made Zoe's ponytail swing wildly. Mia's stomach tightened as she wondered if she would have to sit out the competition entirely.

The music echoed through the gym as pairs of students twirled and stepped in rhythm. Ms. Garcia, the dance teacher, clapped her hands to the beat while calling out instructions. Mia noticed Jake, a quiet boy from her math class, sitting alone on the bleachers. He was tapping his foot to the music but not participating. Their eyes met briefly before Mia quickly looked away. She gathered her courage and walked across the gym floor, dodging dancing couples. The wooden floor squeaked beneath her sneakers as she approached the bleachers. Maybe Jake needed a partner too. Mia's palms felt sweaty as she stood in front of him, trying to find the right words to ask if he wanted to team up.

"Um, Ethan," she managed to say, her voice barely audible over the pop music blaring through the gym speakers. "I noticed you don't have a dance partner yet, and neither do I." She shifted her weight from one foot to the other, staring at the polished wooden floor with its faded basketball court lines. Ethan looked up from his phone, his expression unreadable. The colorful streamers hanging from the ceiling seemed to blur as Mia waited for his response. Around them, other students practiced their steps, laughing and moving confidently across the gym floor. The clock on the wall showed only two weeks until the competition, and Mia knew time was running out to find a partner and learn a routine.

With a deep breath, Mia scanned the gym and spotted Jake sitting alone on the bleachers. He was good at dancing but didn't have a partner either. Gathering her courage, Mia walked over and asked if he wanted to team up. Jake smiled and agreed. For the next two weeks, they practiced every day after school, learning steps and creating their own special moves. On competition day, Mia felt butterflies in her stomach as they waited backstage. When their names were called, they stepped onto the floor together. The music started, and everything they had practiced flowed perfectly. Their final spin earned loud cheers from the audience. They didn't win first place, but their third-place trophy felt like gold to Mia. More importantly, she had made a new friend in Jake, and they both agreed to partner again next year.
